bibl.title: Memorandum on infective properties of yellow fever, by [Henry Rose Carter], [19--]

div1.p: [Carter] discusses the infective properties of yellow fever and the influence of his work on Reed and Lazear.

div1.head: Memorandum on infective properties of yellow fever, by [Henry Rose Carter], [19--]

item.p:
1/ The thesis sustained and proven (pub. May 1900) was that if a case
of yellow fever developed in a clean but infectable environment this en-
vironment became infected immediately (within a few hours)--and this
whether the sick man remained in it or not--but did not become infective--
that is, capable of communicating yellow fever to others in it--until a
considerable time had elapsed. This I called “the period of extrinsic
incubation of yellow fever.” This time I later fixed tentatively as be-
ing minimally somewhat in excess of ten days.

On the basis of this belief--or rather knowledge, for I knew it--the
work at McEnery and Jackson, Miss. was done. The work at McEnery was
done by Haroldson of your Board and myself and it was the first time in
which an epidemic developing in a town in the South in the summer time
had been eliminated by sanitary measures: and this was the measure on
which we depended. The work in Jackson (Hunter: Purnell and myself) was
equally successful, though on a different line, no attempt being made to
eliminate it.

2/ The Italians (Bignami and Marchiafava) had shown (1898, I think,
or maybe /99) that an Anopheles mosquito became infected as soon as she
had received a suitable blood meal from a man with malaria, but did not
become infective--that is, capable of conveying the disease--until a suf-
ficient time (about eleven days) had elapsed for the schizogonic cycle
of the malaria parasite to take place and for the sporozoites to reach
her salivary glands. This time is called “the period of extrinsic incu-
bation of malaria” by Rosenau.

The analogy between my finding and that of the Italians was so close
that the deduction was only natural that the conveyance of yellow fever
and malaria was by the same mechanism.

At any rate this deduction was made, first by Lazear: then Reed:
Reed:

Durham and Walter Meyer, of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine:
Reed's own comment on my findings being: “This spells an insect host!”
Lazear had said (about three weeks previously) “The implication is con-
veyance by a living host.”

It may be noted that the shortest time observed in the experiments
at Quemados between the feeding of Stegomyia on a man sick of yellow fever
to its conveyance of yellow fever was 12 days (in Carroll's case).
